commit.message:
Use time.perf_counter for time measurements

This the reliable, multiplatform, recommended way to measure times when
doing benchmarks, and it is available unconditionally now that we
support Python 3.5+.

commit.message:
Make reader re-creation possible

As it was, the current code made it hard to re-create a reader for the
data we run our benchmark against. This change moves the creation of the
reader object into a small inner function that we now call in a with
block to ensure it's always closed.

Moreover, the reader object has always been created, so there was some
code checking for its existence that shouldn't have been there in the
first place.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 3c59e12b073f90516f01c42c72d4961cb4d8c2ed
parent c2b4c0af72954f740010113aebf8eb4519d7124b
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1684477281 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1701326402 +0800

Make reader re-creation possible

As it was, the current code made it hard to re-create a reader for the
data we run our benchmark against. This change moves the creation of the
reader object into a small inner function that we now call in a with
block to ensure it's always closed.

Moreover, the reader object has always been created, so there was some
code checking for its existence that shouldn't have been there in the
first place.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Remove Python code for compatibility with < 3.5

Most of the compat module dealt with the differences between Python 2
and 3, and now that we don't formally support 2.7 anymore we can finally
remove it. Note that the module itself still contains code for a
different type of compatibility (between strings and bytes), which we
still need to retain.

Additionally, the module defined a flag that helped identifying when the
code was running under 3.5+. This is now always the case, which results
in some simplifications, most notably unconditional import of the
utils35 module, and the ability to define coroutines freely.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 5f65396d4b0399b90aee4bec087f4ba10ba77714
parent f058475a0c70abd10bdee009aa20c01c76fc630c
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1700812840 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1700924993 +0800

Remove Python code for compatibility with < 3.5

Most of the compat module dealt with the differences between Python 2
and 3, and now that we don't formally support 2.7 anymore we can finally
remove it. Note that the module itself still contains code for a
different type of compatibility (between strings and bytes), which we
still need to retain.

Additionally, the module defined a flag that helped identifying when the
code was running under 3.5+. This is now always the case, which results
in some simplifications, most notably unconditional import of the
utils35 module, and the ability to define coroutines freely.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Remove tests support for Python < 3.5

Now that we don't plan to support Python 2.7 and 3.4 anymore, the tests
can be simplified, since they previously catered for these particular
versions in a few places (skipping some tests, adding some more, or
adjusting expectations, on a case-by-case basis).

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Remove Python 2.7 and 3.4 from supported versions

We are planning to remove support for these two versions, which are the
ones bringing the most maintainability overheads, and for very little
gain nowadays, since they both have been discontinued a long time ago.

Now that we only support 3.5+, we don't need to explicitly mention it
anywhere else.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Don't build all wheels all the time

Building wheels, specially on macOS and aarch64, takes a long time.
Instead of building all wheels all the time, let's instead build a
subset of wheels during normal pushes (only x86_64 for each of the three
main OSs), and all wheels only when we push a tag.

Moreover, when we build all wheels we build each OS/arch combination in
a separate job, further speeding up the whole workflow.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 2d0f657f46c234528debc0390261cff7e42191aa
parent c30f083969db685b33586779bcdc1867ce4732fd
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1700030505 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1700808462 +0800

Don't build all wheels all the time

Building wheels, specially on macOS and aarch64, takes a long time.
Instead of building all wheels all the time, let's instead build a
subset of wheels during normal pushes (only x86_64 for each of the three
main OSs), and all wheels only when we push a tag.

Moreover, when we build all wheels we build each OS/arch combination in
a separate job, further speeding up the whole workflow.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Add new job to quickly build and run tests

The wheel-building job is too time consuming and therefore doesn't work
optimally to give feedback in a timely fashion. Moreover, it (currently)
doesn't properly test the compiled C extension, which is our usual
source of problems.

This new workflow defines jobs for common platforms and python versions
to build and test our package. These jobs run all in parallel, with each
one being fairly small, and therefore should give us quick feedback
after a commit is pushed. It also includes testing against the latest
version of PyPy (that includes our fixes), thus ensuring our extension
keeps working against this Python distribution.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 9ea4839b986fdb029fdb3fa1087b0d3712593683
parent 05d8e8c07236df4301895fcbab09a6cb19fb62d6
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1700027929 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1700808462 +0800

Add new job to quickly build and run tests

The wheel-building job is too time consuming and therefore doesn't work
optimally to give feedback in a timely fashion. Moreover, it (currently)
doesn't properly test the compiled C extension, which is our usual
source of problems.

This new workflow defines jobs for common platforms and python versions
to build and test our package. These jobs run all in parallel, with each
one being fairly small, and therefore should give us quick feedback
after a commit is pushed. It also includes testing against the latest
version of PyPy (that includes our fixes), thus ensuring our extension
keeps working against this Python distribution.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Bump Python version used to build sources and binaries

3.7 is EOL, and therefore we're not getting the latest version of
cibuildwheels, since they stopped supporting Python 3.7 a while ago.
This in turn means we are not getting wheels for Python 3.12.

In this commit we're updating our actions to use 3.12 to get the longest
lifetime possible. In the case of the source distribution, we
additionally need to install setuptools since distutils isn't included
in CPython anymore.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 553099dcbc61bf6872020046e8c370086e7be8f5
parent 3a94e5899ea88a406a94ddc217be687e9206be9c
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1696953970 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1696954576 +0800

Bump Python version used to build sources and binaries

3.7 is EOL, and therefore we're not getting the latest version of
cibuildwheels, since they stopped supporting Python 3.7 a while ago.
This in turn means we are not getting wheels for Python 3.12.

In this commit we're updating our actions to use 3.12 to get the longest
lifetime possible. In the case of the source distribution, we
additionally need to install setuptools since distutils isn't included
in CPython anymore.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Fix refcount and make it more intuitive

The chain function in coro_utils was special casing some reference
counting to avoid touching the "sink" argument's reference count, while
at the same time "sink" was the value that the internal "coro" object
was initialised to. This special casing made it difficult to understand
the correctness of the reference counts of "coro" and "sink", which has
led to small refcount bugs over the years.

This commit changes how to handle "sink" entirely by properly owning it
for the duration of the call. Instead of leaving its refcount untouched,
we increase its refcount by one after assigning it to "coro"; after
that, we only care about "coro"'s refcount correctness.

Moreover, this commit also fixes a refcount issue: we were passing
"coro" to PyTuple_SET_ITEM, which steals a reference, without
incrementing "coro"'s refcount ourselves. This issue is in a branch of
the code that ultimately gets triggered only by the "kvitems" and
"items" functions, and in both cases "coro" was the same as "sink",
which in turn corresponded to the internal Py_List object build by the
kvitems/items generators and async generators. Thus, this issue
manifested itself as a "list"-related crash in pypy, and as a "negative
refcount found" for an object of type "list" when running with CPython
debug builds.

This issue was found as part of the crash debugging done in #101.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 495be771ccd07d5433794a2eaee40a709e189e09
parent 9572c625dd4cfd990c26809634931e92c0f9454f
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1689905563 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1689905870 +0800

Fix refcount and make it more intuitive

The chain function in coro_utils was special casing some reference
counting to avoid touching the "sink" argument's reference count, while
at the same time "sink" was the value that the internal "coro" object
was initialised to. This special casing made it difficult to understand
the correctness of the reference counts of "coro" and "sink", which has
led to small refcount bugs over the years.

This commit changes how to handle "sink" entirely by properly owning it
for the duration of the call. Instead of leaving its refcount untouched,
we increase its refcount by one after assigning it to "coro"; after
that, we only care about "coro"'s refcount correctness.

Moreover, this commit also fixes a refcount issue: we were passing
"coro" to PyTuple_SET_ITEM, which steals a reference, without
incrementing "coro"'s refcount ourselves. This issue is in a branch of
the code that ultimately gets triggered only by the "kvitems" and
"items" functions, and in both cases "coro" was the same as "sink",
which in turn corresponded to the internal Py_List object build by the
kvitems/items generators and async generators. Thus, this issue
manifested itself as a "list"-related crash in pypy, and as a "negative
refcount found" for an object of type "list" when running with CPython
debug builds.

This issue was found as part of the crash debugging done in #101.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Build StopIteration exception fully

When raising exceptions from a C extension via PyErr_SetObject(type,
value), they can be normalised or not. In the normalised case, "value"
is an instance of the exception type (e.g., "value =
StopIteration(args)"), while the latter simply passes the arguments that
would be given when constructing the exception type instance, without
constricting it (following the example above, "value = args").

Historically we have had no issues with raising non-normalised
exceptions. However, this doesn't currently work with PyPy (reported in
https://foss.heptapod.net/pypy/pypy/-/issues/3965). Raising normalised
exceptions *does* work though, so we choose to do that instead.

Note that contrary to a comment in that issue, performance *is* impacted
for CPython if we choose to always raise normalised exceptions (local
tests show ~10-20% degradation, depending on the test case). We
therefore do this only when building against PyPy, leaving CPython
working as previously.

This issue was spotted in #101.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 2a25af14acff26ab29bdeae9fd9385627ef8ea1f
parent 001e56db43466842a35e25cdbdfcd1d722f3b9bc
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1689833809 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1689839177 +0800

Build StopIteration exception fully

When raising exceptions from a C extension via PyErr_SetObject(type,
value), they can be normalised or not. In the normalised case, "value"
is an instance of the exception type (e.g., "value =
StopIteration(args)"), while the latter simply passes the arguments that
would be given when constructing the exception type instance, without
constricting it (following the example above, "value = args").

Historically we have had no issues with raising non-normalised
exceptions. However, this doesn't currently work with PyPy (reported in
https://foss.heptapod.net/pypy/pypy/-/issues/3965). Raising normalised
exceptions *does* work though, so we choose to do that instead.

Note that contrary to a comment in that issue, performance *is* impacted
for CPython if we choose to always raise normalised exceptions (local
tests show ~10-20% degradation, depending on the test case). We
therefore do this only when building against PyPy, leaving CPython
working as previously.

This issue was spotted in #101.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Raise exception after calling DelSlice

When raising a StopIteration exception to return a value for our
coroutine, we were raising it before calling PySequence_DelSlice. This
was incorrect, because one should not invoke further python functions
when an exception has been set, otherwise those further invocations
would return non-NULL values with an exception set. Normal python builds
don't care about this, but python debug builds catch these errors, which
can be otherwise difficult to debug.

This commit re-organises our code so we clear our internal list *before*
we raise the exception, so there are no further Python functions invoked
after the exception is set.

This issue was found while debugging PyPy crashes in #101, even though
it's not necessarily the case that those crashes were caused by this
problem.
